model.hed: Best Hotels and Resorts in Egypt: 2012
model.dek: Hotels and resorts in Egypt on Condé Nast Traveler's 2012 Gold List: The World's Best Places to Stay

fields.title: [Africa & the Middle East](http://www.cntraveler.com/gold-list/2012/africa-middle-east)
fields.caption: This ten-year-old hillside [Four Seasons Resort, Sharm El Sheikh](http://www.cntraveler.com/gold-list/2012/africa-middle-east/egypt-best-hotels-resorts-gold-list-2012) is done in a moorish style, replete with towers, arabesques, and moucharabies and overlooking the Sinai Peninsula. Overall score: 98.6

Overall score: 98.6

items.name: Four Seasons Resort, Sharm El Sheikh, Sharm El Sheikh
items.description: This ten-year-old hillside Moorish-style resort—replete with towers, arabesques, and moucharabies and overlooking the Sinai Peninsula—"is like the Garden of Eden." Eighteen hundred palm trees line the driveway to the open-air lobby, where "the flower arrangements are amazing." Brick villas arranged in clusters have rooms in browns and creams; most come with balconies facing the Red Sea. "In every area of the resort, staff went out of their way to provide above-and-beyond service"—poolside, they keep guests cool with mist sprays. Arabesque serves Middle Eastern cuisine, while Il Frantoio dishes up Italian. Get a coffee-and-milk scrub at the spa. "It's my favorite resort in the whole wide world."

fields.title: [Africa & the Middle East](http://www.cntraveler.com/gold-list/2012/africa-middle-east)
fields.caption: This ten-year-old hillside [Four Seasons Resort, Sharm El Sheikh](http://www.cntraveler.com/gold-list/2012/africa-middle-east/egypt-best-hotels-resorts-gold-list-2012) is done in a moorish style, replete with towers, arabesques, and moucharabies and overlooking the Sinai Peninsula. Overall score: 98.6

items.name: Semiramis InterContinental Cairo, Cairo
items.description: Named for the Assyrian queen Semiramis, this "excellent high-rise" with hanging gardens is in "a great location" facing the Nile and near the Egyptian Museum and Cairo Opera House. Rooms with balconies have modern French decor and Elemis or L'Occitane bathroom amenities. Eleven "generally good" restaurants offer a variety of cuisines, from Lebanese to Italian to French. At Night & Day, patrons dine near cooking stations where they can watch chefs prepping sushi and teppanyaki. After dinner, step through the Arabian Nights-style doors of Rithmo for a late-night cocktail. "The wonderful staff are very helpful."

items.name: Four Seasons Hotel Alexandria at San Stefano, Alexandria
items.description: The first luxury hotel to open in Egypt’s second city since the Belle Epoque, the Four Seasons occupies the former site of the colonial-era Hotel San Stefano. While the 118-room tower adjoins a huge modern condo- and shopping mall–complex, inside it manages to feel like an exclusive landmark and retains much of the esprit—including an attentive liveried staff—of the Deauville-inspired original. Designer Pierre-Yves Rochon has given rooms warm yellow tones, Roman-style baths, and neoclassic furniture. A round infinity pool on the fourth-floor terrace gives guests the sensation of sitting by the Mediterranean Sea (a tunnel links the hotel to a private beach), while Alexandria’s nouveau beau monde has taken to the public areas, adopting the Lebanese-inspired gallery with hand-painted murals, a hothouse garden, and a third-floor terrace café as their playground.

items.name: Four Seasons Hotel Cairo at Nile Plaza, Cairo
items.description: This 20-story glass tower near high-end shopping and next to the Zoological Gardens is "first-class all the way." Gold, red, and green rooms come with full marble bathrooms, "the most comfortable bed linens," and "perfect views of the Pyramids" on clear days. Lai Thai serves signature dishes like satay ruam—grilled chicken and beef with curried peanut sauce—prepared by Thai chefs. While the overall decor "needs a bit of an update," "staff are outstanding." At the spa, try the Pharaonic massage, a royal treatment that employs heated aromatic poultices.

items.name: Four Seasons Hotel Cairo at The First Residence
items.description: Located between the Giza Zoo and the Nile in one of the city's tonier, greener suburbs.

fields.title: Four Seasons Cairo at the First Residence
fields.caption:
**


 Overall Score: 89.7**


See full rating information for **[Four Seasons Cairo at the First Residence](/hotels/africa-middle-east/egypt/four-seasons-hotel-cairo-at-the-first-residence-cairo-egypt)**

items.name: Cairo Marriott Hotel & Omar Khayyam Casino, Cairo
items.description: The broad tower sits beside the Belle Époque and Art Deco mansions of the Garden City district. "Staff never disappoint," and the food in the seven restaurants is "a fine combination of traditional Middle Eastern specialties and Western and Asian staples." Most rooms have outdoor terraces, soaking tubs, and bright decor. "I’m always sad to check out."

fields.title: [Mena House Oberoi](/hotels/africa-middle-east/egypt/mena-house-oberoi-cairo-cairo-egypt)
fields.caption: “The Mena House Oberoi, in Cairo. How can you beat waking up to a view of the Pyramids at Giza [20-2-33-77-3222; doubles from $233].”—_Sanjay Surana, editor, [Gold List 2013](/gold-list/2013)_

items.name: Old Cataract Hotel
items.description: An iconic hotel, built on a granite cliff facing Elephantine Island in 1899. A three-year makeover by the Sofitel chain has reduced the number of rooms by half and increased the proportion of suites. The colonial-era palace has 76 rooms with gold and maroon interiors and sunset Nile views; the modern tower wing has 62 rooms, all with Nile-facing balconies, and a sumptuous new spa. Rooms have deep tubs or rain showers, all with Hermès toiletries. If you’ve ever been tempted to pack a vintage tuxedo or evening gown, this place provides the perfect backdrop. The restored 1902 restaurant, modeled after Cairo’s Ibn Tulun mosque, looks like a film set for Death on the Nile. Art Deco meets Mamluk glamour in the chandeliered palace, its halls adorned with photographs of royals, artists, and other luminaries who’ve stayed here. The tower’s contemporary decor echoes ancient Egyptian motifs.

fields.caption: An iconic hotel, built on a granite cliff facing Elephantine Island in 1899. A three-year makeover by the Sofitel chain has reduced the number of rooms by half and increased the proportion of suites. The colonial-era palace has 76 rooms with gold and maroon interiors and sunset Nile views; the modern tower wing has 62 rooms, all with Nile-facing balconies, and a sumptuous new spa. Rooms have deep tubs or rain showers, all with Hermès toiletries. [Read More](/hotels/africa-middle-east/egypt/sofitel-legend-aswan-egypt)

items.name: Villa Belle Epoque
items.description: Occupying conjoined 1920s villas in Maadi, a leafy suburb created to house British civil servants and Egyptians working in the court of the Khedive Abbas Hilmi II, this whitewashed structure with dark colonial green window casings and balcony trim. Egyptian owner Tarek El Gendy and his Dutch wife, Beryl, have filled the 32 guest suites with a tasteful mix of contemporary Egyptian art and European and Oriental antiques. Guests can curl up in a library stocked with design magazines and books on Egyptian art and history, or lay by the pool in a lush garden of mature mango, acacia, and date palm trees. Both restaurants serve typical Egyptian dishes (the chef stirs coconut into his baba ghanoush, a tasty twist on an Egyptian classic). Amid the quiet neighborhood of historic villas, mosques, a synagogue, and low-rise apartment buildings, the hotel is a five-minute stroll to Road Nine, Maadi’s main street, popular for its mix of vegetable sellers and small souks offering shisha pipes, cartouches, and other souvenirs. The Cairo Metro stops here on the way to Coptic Cairo and Tahrir Square, while the Pyramids are 30 minutes away by car. The helpful hotel staff can arrange taxis, feluccas, and private guides.

items.name: Sofitel El Gezirah Cairo, Cairo
items.description: "I can't stop talking about how wonderful the hotel is!" This cylindrical tower, in the upscale Zamalek business district on El Gezirah Island, was built to ensure that all rooms have Nile views. Interiors designed by Pierre-Yves Rochon include a lobby with a marbled hall, wooden ceiling, and Egyptian crystal chandelier. Accommodations are done in tones of light green or terra-cotta. El Kebabgy offers barbecued meat grilled in front of the diner and 25 flavors of shisha. Buddha Bar lounge, with a DJ, signature cocktails, and an open-air terrace, draws night owls. The spa has a hammam.

items.name: Al Tarfa Desert Sanctuary Lodge & Spa
items.description: Scattered between ancient date trees half buried in sand, farm plots, and low rocky hills dotted with fox dens and potsherds attesting to millennia of human settlement, Al Tarfa’s 20 free-standing villas reference the geometric motifs of Dakhla Oasis’s eleventh-century mud-brick and palm-wood architecture. Rooms situated to take advantage of the view are variously decorated with wrought iron beds, carved wood tables, and local textiles; all have outdoor terraces and some have fireplaces and private plunge pools. The place is especially romantic at night, with paths lit by cut-out clay vases, straw birdcages, and other traditional objects repurposed as lanterns. There’s a central lounge bar, a pool, a riding stable, and a small but exquisite spa to satisfy guests who want to chill out between desert camping and pharaonic sightseeing excursions. And Al Tarfa is also a soft-adventure destination: The room rate includes private camel rides in the dunes and walking or 4x4 visits to local pharaonic and Islamic ruins, living villages, and geological points of interest such as natural hot springs.
